messages.content: I've been really frustrated with my development workflow lately. Every time I switch between projects, I lose so much time setting up my environment again.
That's a common pain point. Are you using any containerization like Docker, or virtual environments? What kind of projects are you typically switching between?
Mostly Python and Node.js projects. I use venv for Python and nvm for Node, but it's still a hassle. I have to remember which Python version, which Node version, what env vars to set...

Have you looked into tools like direnv for automatic environment loading, or mise (formerly rtx) for managing multiple runtime versions? They can automatically activate the right versions when you cd into a project.

I haven't tried mise, that looks interesting. But honestly what I really want is something that captures my ENTIRE project context - not just versions, but which terminal tabs I had open, which files I was editing, even my browser tabs related to the project.

That's an interesting idea - a full project context manager. There are some tools that do parts of this (like Workspaces in VS Code), but nothing that captures everything including browser state. Are you thinking of building something like this?

Yeah, I've been sketching out ideas. I'd call it something like 'ContextSwitch' or 'ProjectPod'. The hard part would be capturing and restoring browser state - that probably needs a browser extension.

A browser extension for the browser state, combined with a CLI tool that manages the dev environment side, could work. You could store project contexts as JSON files. What would the restore process look like ideally?

I'd just run something like 'pod switch myproject' and it would: switch to the right terminal directory, activate the right environment, open my editor with the files I had open, and restore my browser tabs in a window group.
That's ambitious but definitely achievable in stages. You could start with just the terminal/environment piece, then add editor integration, then browser. Each piece has value on its own.
True. Speaking of side projects, I also want to build a better bookmark manager. I have thousands of bookmarks across three browsers and they're completely disorganized.
Bookmark management is definitely a mess for most people. What would make yours better than existing solutions?
Auto-tagging with AI, dead link detection, and most importantly - a way to actually FIND things again. I bookmark stuff and then never find it when I need it.
Search and discovery is the key problem. You could use embeddings to enable semantic search - 'find that article about React performance' even if those exact words aren't in the title or tags.
Exactly! And maybe show related bookmarks when I'm on a webpage. Like 'you saved 5 similar articles about this topic'. That would be so useful for research.

A browser extension could detect the current page topic and surface relevant bookmarks. You could use something like sentence-transformers for the embeddings. Would you store data locally or in the cloud?
Local first, definitely. I don't want my browsing history in someone else's cloud. Maybe optional sync between my own devices.
Local-first with optional self-hosted sync is a great approach. SQLite for storage, maybe Syncthing or similar for device sync. What's your experience with browser extension development?
I built a simple one years ago with the old Firefox addon SDK. I know things have changed a lot with WebExtensions. I'd need to learn the new APIs.

The WebExtensions API is actually pretty nice now and works cross-browser. Manifest V3 has some limitations but for a bookmark manager it should be fine. You'd need content scripts to analyze pages and a background service worker for the storage/sync logic.
This is exciting. Though I keep starting projects and not finishing them. I have like 10 half-done repos on my GitHub.
That's common! What tends to make you abandon projects? Scope creep, losing motivation, or something else?

Mostly I get stuck on something tedious and then a new shiny idea comes along. Like with my last project - a CLI tool for managing dotfiles - I got bogged down in edge cases for symlink handling and just... stopped.
The dotfiles manager is a useful tool though! There are existing ones like chezmoi and yadm, but building your own teaches you a lot. Maybe you could scope it down to just the features YOU need?
Yeah, I was trying to handle every possible edge case instead of just making it work for my setup. I should revisit it with a simpler scope. Just: track these files, sync them to this repo, done.
Exactly - an MVP for your own use case first. If it works for you, others with similar setups might find it useful too. What files do you typically want to track?

Mainly shell configs (.zshrc, aliases), editor configs (nvim), and git config. Maybe 20 files total. Definitely don't need to handle installing packages or bootstrapping a new machine - that's where I over-scoped before.
20 files with symlink tracking is very doable. A simple Python script that reads a manifest, creates symlinks, and can push/pull from a git repo. You could have a working version in an afternoon.
You're right. I should just timebox it - give myself 4 hours this weekend and see what I can get working. No perfectionism allowed.

Timeboxing is a great strategy! Document what you cut from scope so you know what to add later if you want. The goal is a working tool that solves YOUR problem, not a perfect tool that solves everyone's.
Thanks, this has been really helpful for sorting out my thoughts. I think the priority is: 1) finish dotfiles tool, 2) build the bookmark manager, 3) maybe tackle ProjectPod eventually.

That's a solid prioritization! Starting small and building momentum. The dotfiles tool might even help with ProjectPod later - you'll understand environment management better. Good luck with the weekend build!
